recipes.title: Mrs. Reese's Pressed Cheese
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian cheese-making from Foxfire Book 4
recipes.description: A traditional pressed cheese that forms a dry crust and keeps for a month or more. Uses rennet tablets to curdle the milk.

instructions.text: Pour all the milk into a large pan and heat on a wood stove (for slower, steadier heat) until a little past lukewarm.
Remove from heat and add the dissolved rennet tablet and color tablet.
Let sit for 15-30 minutes until the milk stiffens and becomes jelly-like.
Cut the curd with a knife or spatula into tiny squares, also running the spatula under the surface as if cutting it into layers.
Let sit briefly, then gently work the mixture until broken into pieces the size of grains of corn.
Return pan to stove and heat slowly, stirring constantly, until almost as hot as the touch can stand but not boiling.
Remove from heat and let sit 15-30 minutes to cool.
Strain contents through cheesecloth in a colander. Let drip naturally, do not squeeze.
Return curds to pan, add the salt, and massage it in well.
Put curds into a homemade press lined with cheesecloth. Add weight in stages and leave overnight (12 hours).
Remove from press and dry in open air for one week, turning twice daily. The cheese forms a dry crust on the outside.

notes: Before rennet tablets were available, a piece of dried cow stomach lining (about thumbnail size) was used to curdle the milk.
A wood stove is preferred for its slower, steadier heat.
The cheese keeps for a month or more without refrigeration.

recipes.title: Mrs. Thelma Earp's Quick Fried Cheese
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian cheese-making from Foxfire Book 4
recipes.description: A quick cheese that can be eaten right away, made by frying curds in butter. Forms a cake as it cools.

ingredients.prep_note: raw, barnyard eggs preferred for color

instructions.text: Allow cream to rise on whole milk, skim it off and make butter.
Add 2-3 tablespoons buttermilk per gallon of skimmed milk and let sit out for two days to sour.
Refrigerate the clabbered milk until ready to use.
Pour clabbered milk into a pan and heat until a little hotter than lukewarm (pretty hot but not boiling, won't burn hands).
Pour into a strainer made with cotton cloth pinned over a bucket. Squeeze the whey through, leaving curds.
Put curds in a bowl, add salt and raw egg. Mix with hands.
Melt butter in a large iron frying pan. Prefer wood stove for even, slow heat.
Add curds and keep turning in the pan over medium heat until all curds melt and run together into a cake.
Put out into a dish to cool. It automatically forms a cake as it cools.

notes: Can be eaten right away or kept several days.
Do not refrigerate - it should dry out somewhat.
After a short while it gets hard enough to cut into slices.
Feed the whey to the hogs.

recipes.title: Appalachian Cottage Cheese
recipes.attribution: Mrs. Harriet Echols and Mrs. Nora Garland, via Foxfire 4
recipes.source_note: Traditional Appalachian cottage cheese from Foxfire Book 4
recipes.description: Simple cottage cheese made by clabbering raw milk, then heating and draining the curds.

instructions.text: Pour raw milk into an enamel or metal pan.
Let sit on back of wood stove (winter) or kitchen table (warm weather) to sour slowly. Takes 1-2 days depending on temperature.
After milk clabbers, lift off the cream and refrigerate (can be used as sour cream or mixed back in later).
Heat the skimmed clabbered milk over low fire until it curdles.
Remove from heat and pour into a colander or cheesecloth to drain. Takes a couple of hours. Can hang in a clean flour sack overnight.
Work the cheese by squeezing with hands or spoon to remove remaining water. Don't work too vigorously or get curds too fine.
Sprinkle in salt to taste. For creamier cheese, mix in some of the reserved sour cream.
Package in small containers and refrigerate. Keeps several weeks.

notes: Do not heat the milk before it clabbers.
Mrs. Garland put the curdled milk in a clean flour sack and let it drain outside overnight.
